material.mattext:
Example of an Entisolic Soil


Example of a Vertisolic Soil

Entisolic soils have little or no evidence of development of pedogenic horizons. Many are sandy or very shallow.

Vertisolic soils have a high content of clay. They shrink when drying and have deep wide cracks at some time of the year.

Based on the pictures and the information provided above, the percolation rate would be highest for soil that was made up of
an upper layer containing entisolic soil and a lower layer of vertisolic soil.
an upper layer of vertisolic soil and a lower layer of entisolic soil.

respcondition.title: 0 an upper layer containing entisols and a lo

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 0 an upper layer containing entisols and a lo

respcondition.title: 1 an upper layer of vertisols and a lower lay

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 an upper layer of vertisols and a lower lay

itemfeedback.ident: 0 an upper layer containing entisols and a lo
1 an upper layer of vertisols and a lower lay

the point at which the line for field capacity and the line for wilting point would meet.
the difference between the line for field capacity and the line for wilting point.
the point at which a vertical line would divide the area in half.
the point at which a horizontal line would divide the area in half.

material.mattext:
Example of an Entisolic Soil


Example of a Vertisolic Soil

Entisolic soils have little or no evidence of development of pedogenic horizons. Many are sandy or very shallow.

Vertisolic soils have a high content of clay. They shrink when drying and have deep wide cracks at some time of the year.

Base on the information provided, one can assume that
vertisolic soils would not easily support plant life.
water would easily percolate through vertisolic soils.
entisolic soils would not easily support plant life.

respcondition.title: 0 vertisolic soil would not easily support pl

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 0 vertisolic soil would not easily support pl

respcondition.title: 1 water would easily drain through vertisolic

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 water would easily drain through vertisolic

respcondition.title: 2 entisolic soil cannot support plant life.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 entisolic soil cannot support plant life.

itemfeedback.ident: 0 vertisolic soil would not easily support pl
1 water would easily drain through vertisolic
2 entisolic soil cannot support plant life.

material.mattext: The texture of the soil is the same for all the fields represented in the graph above. If all of the fields have received the same amount of precipitation, which field has the most available water?
Based on the information provided by graph above, which of the following statements is true?
Strong bonds between particles in fine grain soils lead to more available water capacity.
Sand has the highest available water capacity because of the large spaces between soil particles.
Available water capacity is determined by adding the field capacity and the wilting point.
Porosity and soil type influence the available water capacity.

respcondition.title: 0 Strong bonds between particles in fine grai

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 Sand has the highest available water becaus

respcondition.title: 2 Available water is determined by adding the

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 Available water is determined by adding the

respcondition.title: 3 Porosity and soil type influence the amount

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 Porosity and soil type influence the amount

1 Sand has the highest available water becaus
2 Available water is determined by adding the
3 Porosity and soil type influence the amount

A researcher collected information on four different soil samples, which is recorded in the table above.  Using the table, determine which soil sample has the largest available water capacity?
Which of the following is the best way to increase the water retention of soils?
All other things being equal, which of the following actions should increase available water?
Increase the amount of dead plant and animal matter in the soil.
Decrease the amount of dead plant and animal matter in the soil.
It depends on the ratio of dead plant matter to animal matter.
Minimize the occurrence of natural composting.

respcondition.title: 0 Increased content of dead plant and dead an

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 0 Increased content of dead plant and dead an

respcondition.title: 1 Decreased content of dead plant and dead an

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 Decreased content of dead plant and dead an

respcondition.title: 2 A stable mix of dead plant matter and dead

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 A stable mix of dead plant matter and dead

respcondition.title: 3 Minimizing the occurrence of natural compos

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 Minimizing the occurrence of natural compos

itemfeedback.ident: 0 Increased content of dead plant and dead an
1 Decreased content of dead plant and dead an
2 A stable mix of dead plant matter and dead
3 Minimizing the occurrence of natural compos

Available water has nothing to do with the type of soils.

material.mattext: The amount of water in the soil that can be used by plants is the
Which of the following is involved in controlling field capacity?
the amount of yield a field produces in the fall harvest
the texture of the soil in the field
the amount of water absorbed through transpiration
the size of the field relative to the amount of crops planted

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 0 The amount of yield a field produces in the

respcondition.title: 1 The texture of the soil in the field.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 The texture of the soil in the field.

respcondition.title: 2 The amount of water absorbed through transp

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 The amount of water absorbed through transp

respcondition.title: 3 The size of the field relative to the amoun

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 The size of the field relative to the amoun

material.mattext: You have analyzed the amount of water in six soil samples brought to your school from six different farmers' fields. You found that one has no water at all. How would you describe the level of soil water in this field?
no soil water available to plants.
soil water available only to plants under stress.
soil water readily available to plants.
soil water readily draining from the field

respcondition.title: 1 available only to plants under stress.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 available only to plants under stress.

itemfeedback.ident: 1 available only to plants under stress.

material.mattext: Which of the following describes the rate at which water moves through soil?

After analyzing a soil sample, you find that the amount of space around the soil particles is very low, so the soil can only hold a small amount of water. Your analysis leads you to decide that the soil has
When the available water in a field is at the field capacity, that field
will absorb more water when it rains.
is at the permanent wilting point.
will increase in field capacity when it rains.
How can a farmer determine the available water capacity of her field?
Find the amount of rainfall during that season and subtract the permanent wilting level.
Calculate the proportion of soil water relative to the amount of ground water.
Add the field capacity and the permanent wilting level.
Subtract the permanent wilting level from the field capacity.

respcondition.title: 0 Find the amount of rainfall during that sea

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 0 Find the amount of rainfall during that sea

respcondition.title: 1 Calculate the proportion of soil water rela

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 Calculate the proportion of soil water rela

respcondition.title: 2 Add the field capacity and the permanent wi

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 Add the field capacity and the permanent wi

respcondition.title: 3 Find the field capacity and subtract the pe

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 Find the field capacity and subtract the pe

itemfeedback.ident: 0 Find the amount of rainfall during that sea
1 Calculate the proportion of soil water rela
2 Add the field capacity and the permanent wi
3 Find the field capacity and subtract the pe

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 is greater than the maximum possible availa

2 is greater than the maximum possible availa

material.mattext: When water is so tightly bound to soil particles that a plant's roots cannot extract it, this is called the

item.title: MC Definition - Wilting Point - retired
item.qticomment: AUTHOR The Learning Partnership NAME Retirment Explanation DATE June 01, 2002 15:47:03 This item was originally used in testing with Janet Bell-Wehr May 2002. The prompt was based on text that only appeared in the teacher notes. It was changed to reflect text that appeared in the curriculum.

material.mattext: When the extractive force of a plant's roots is equal to the soil capillary force, this is called the
The permanent wilting point refers to the point at which
a field cannot hold any more water.
there is no water in a field.
plants cannot extract the water in a field.
water is immediately available for plants to use.

respcondition.title: 0 the maximum amount of water that a field ca

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 0 the maximum amount of water that a field ca

respcondition.title: 1 no water exist on a field.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 no water exist on a field.

respcondition.title: 2 no more water can be taken out of the soil

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 no more water can be taken out of the soil

respcondition.title: 3 the water is immediately available to natur

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 the water is immediately available to natur

itemfeedback.ident: 0 the maximum amount of water that a field ca
1 no water exist on a field.
2 no more water can be taken out of the soil
3 the water is immediately available to natur

material.mattext:
A farmer recently examined the soil in his fields. The following are some of the characteristics he found.

  • The soil contains a high amount of sand.
  • Soil oxygen levels appear high.
  • The water level in the soil is approximately 50% of the field capacity.

Based on the above information, which of the following would be true about the soil?
The soil drains freely and can become very dry.
There is little space between particles.
The soil has small particles and a large surface area.
There is a lot of organic matter present in the soil.

respcondition.title: 0 The soil drains freely and is very dry.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 0 The soil drains freely and is very dry.

respcondition.title: 1 There is little space between particles.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 There is little space between particles.

respcondition.title: 2 The soil has small particles and a large surface

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 The soil has small particles and a large surface

respcondition.title: 3 There is a lot of organic matter present.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 There is a lot of organic matter present.

itemfeedback.ident: 0 The soil drains freely and is very dry.
1 There is little space between particles.
2 The soil has small particles and a large surface
3 There is a lot of organic matter present.

material.mattext: You can expect soils with a gritty texture to
be smaller in diameter than silt.
be smaller in diameter than clay.

respcondition.title: 2 be smaller in diameter than silt.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 be smaller in diameter than silt.

respcondition.title: 3 be smaller in diameter than clay.

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 be smaller in diameter than clay.

itemfeedback.ident: 2 be smaller in diameter than silt.
3 be smaller in diameter than clay.

material.mattext: Your neighbor brings you a sample of soil from her yard. She wants to plant a garden and is seeking your advice on whether the soil is suitable for growing vegetables. Upon examining the soil you determine that 70% of it is clay. What should you tell your neighbor about her soil?
The clay in the soil has made it rough and gritty as a result of the weathering of bedrock.
The organic matter in the soil decreases the temperature stability and causes a poor crop yield.
The garden could become waterlogged because the surface area of the soil particles holds large amounts of water.
The garden will drain too quickly because the large pore spaces around the soil particles cannot hold water tightly enough.

respcondition.title: 0 The clay in the soil has made it rough and

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 0 The clay in the soil has made it rough and

respcondition.title: 1 The organic matter in the soil decreases th

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 1 The organic matter in the soil decreases th

respcondition.title: 2 It could become waterlogged because the par

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 2 It could become waterlogged because the par

respcondition.title: 3 It will drain too quickly because the large

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 It will drain too quickly because the large

itemfeedback.ident: 0 The clay in the soil has made it rough and
1 The organic matter in the soil decreases th
2 It could become waterlogged because the par
3 It will drain too quickly because the large

material.mattext: In an experiment, 5 cm of water is added to soil in a carton. The carton is fitted with drainage holes leading to a beaker. After an hour, only 1 cm of water is collected in the beaker. The soil in the carton has
Which of the following does NOT affect the volume of pore space in soil?
According to the texture triangle above, which of the following soil combinations would produce silt loam?
Water moves through soil in several ways. Water movement is aided by the
Water that a plant's roots absorb from the soil is referred to as
Which type of water is bound to other water molecules and, thus, can only be removed by either air drying or by plant absorption?
One type of soil water can be bound to a soil particle by forces as great as 10,000 bars. This force makes it impossible for gravity to remove it. What type of soil water does this describe?
What type of soil water is found as a microscopic film of water surrounding soil particles?
